stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews and begins integrating Biobak’s major visual/geometry overhaul of Course 11 (an industrial Oily Boily Bay remake with factory/office/underground areas), identifies export/render/material issues, and outlines plans to redo collision and fix crashes. He also discusses a strategy to re-release a Course 1–only demo for systematic camera/physics playtesting, shows a new Goomba-bounce movement mechanic, and goes on extended design/philosophy tangents about color theory and ‘humility’ vs confidence.
stream_context.significance_reason: Large, shippable-looking art/geometry update for Course 11 is reviewed and partially integrated (with concrete follow-up tasks: collision remake, crash fixes, material/layer ordering). Kaze also commits to a new demo strategy (Course 1 only) aimed at gathering structured playtest data for camera/physics tuning, which affects overall development workflow.

findings.summary: Kaze considers releasing a new demo containing only Course 1 (instead of multiple courses) so he can continuously iterate on camera and movement physics based on player feedback, without having to keep several levels updated with each engine change.
findings.quote: The idea is that I will just keep updating the demo and optimizing Course 1 so I can have everything be playtested all the time.

findings.summary: He plans to ship the Course 1 demo alongside a structured feedback form (Google Doc) to collect specific notes on camera behavior and Mario controls, with the explicit goal of tuning variables until movement feels “perfect.”
findings.quote: I'm going to release it along with a Google document where people can give feedback on what they like and didn't like about the way Mario controls.

findings.summary: Kaze shows a new movement feature: after bouncing on a Goomba, holding A gives a higher jump and restores some control midair—intended to evoke 2D Mario’s bounce feel and improve overall flow.
findings.quote: If you hold the A button, you jump higher and you regain some control of Mario—kind of like the old 2D Mario games.

findings.summary: He claims the project’s expanded movement set (e.g., dive/double jump, fewer ‘no-input’ animation frames) makes vanilla SM64 feel hard to return to, reinforcing that movement feel is becoming a core identity of the hack.
findings.quote: You can't go back to vanilla Mario 64 after playing with these.

findings.summary: Biobak’s Course 11 remake significantly changes the level’s look via more vibrant color, revised lighting rationale (removing “nose-based shading” and single-light assumptions), new brutalist Bowser Tower/office vibes, and extensive detailing across areas including underwater/factory/office.

Kaze identifies pipeline friction moving to newer Blender/Fast64 versions: user material presets appear missing/relocated in Blender 4.x, slowing his ability to rapidly reapply standard N64 material setups (e.g., VColor+fog presets).

Course 11 import/export mostly works immediately (surprising to Kaze), but the in-game result reveals multiple issues: missing paths/collision mismatch (old collision map vs new geo), missing fog/material settings, and occasional render oddities (including areas being visible when they shouldn’t be).

He flags a broader rendering-order problem: transparent decals shouldn’t render after transparent surfaces, and he suggests swapping layer usage (layer 6 vs 5) potentially across the whole game to make the ordering consistent.

Biobak’s update appears to reduce geometry load in places (Kaze notes ~1,700 fewer triangles in one section; later sees ~4,400 triangles in a viewed chunk and dismisses it as acceptable), easing performance concerns in what he calls the most ‘GameCube-looking’ map so far.

They discuss multiple optional ‘juice’ upgrades for Course 11: spark particles moving along an electric generator, light pulsing/animation in factory areas, elevator camera and possibly elevator music to reduce awkward camera framing.

Kaze responds to external critique that some background billboard Koopa art doesn’t match the project’s broader style, and considers revising those faces for consistency even though it’s ‘in-world art.’

Kaze rejects formulaic ‘color theory’ rules as non-empirical and argues visual choices should start from intended emotion/mood, then use tools to evoke that feeling—rather than picking colors from harmony charts.
findings.quote: The point is not to just pick random colors—the point is: think of an emotion, and then think about how you can use the tools in your arsenal to evoke this emotion.

findings.summary: He goes on a strong tangent against performative humility, arguing that what matters is willingness to change your mind; he frames ‘acting humble’ as often conflict-avoidant and not inherently virtuous.
findings.quote: Acting humble is a coward's tactic.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivers a sweeping Course 11 visual overhaul: more vibrant palette, revised textures/UVs, new industrial props (containers, fans, cranes), brutalist Bowser Tower/office re-theme, and major underwater/factory detailing; Kaze repeatedly reacts that it looks “insane” and significantly better.

Biobak proposes/requests multiple animated ‘life’ elements (pulsing lights, scrolling treadmill textures, factory effects) and an elaborate hamster-wheel Koopa easter egg room concept with interactive state changes (lights flicker, pipes ‘turn off’) when talked to.

Biobak suggests multiple asset variants (e.g., many versions of a prism with different vertex colors/UVs) to prevent lighting looking ‘off,’ which Kaze acknowledges is doable but annoying—implying a tradeoff between art direction and pipeline complexity.

findings.summary: Lilaa attempts to help Kaze locate Blender/Fast64 preset directories and suggests exporting/testing quickly; the exchange highlights the team’s friction during Blender 4.x migration and how dependent Kaze’s workflow is on reusable presets.
A viewer critique (referenced from a clips show) prompts Kaze to re-evaluate billboard character art style consistency in the background of Course 11.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The point is not to just pick random colors—the point is: think of an emotion, and then think about how you can use the tools in your arsenal to evoke this emotion.
memorable_quotes.context: His pushback against ‘color theory’ as a rulebook; reframes art direction as emotion-first, tool-second.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Acting humble is a coward's tactic.
memorable_quotes.context: A sharp personal philosophy statement during a tangent about confidence, feedback, and internet behavior.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I do not believe in democracy.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while rejecting the idea of letting players vote on what content/features to add; reveals his auteur approach to decision-making.

key_stories.title: Course 11 visual overhaul integration (and the collision-map regret)
key_stories.summary: Kaze receives and reviews Biobak’s dramatically improved Course 11 remake, exports it, and tests it in-game. The new visuals impress him, but the update exposes pipeline and implementation debt—especially collision and material correctness—that he now must pay down to make the level shippable and showcase-ready.
key_stories.challenge: A big art/geometry update must be integrated without breaking rendering, fog/material setup, collision, and area streaming (including at least one crashy area).
key_stories.process: Kaze exports the new level, compares changelog items, checks triangle counts/material deduplication, identifies missing fog/VColor settings and rendering-order issues, and realizes the collision map is outdated relative to the new layout.
key_stories.outcome: He decides he’ll rebuild the collision map and fix crashes off-stream, aiming to later showcase Course 11 on the main channel.
key_stories.key_quote: I shouldn't have done a collision map before Biobak was done—biggest mistake of my life.

key_stories.title: A new demo plan: Course 1 as the permanent camera/physics testbed
key_stories.summary: Instead of keeping multiple courses updated with every engine change, Kaze pivots demo strategy toward a continuously updated Course 1-only build. He frames the demo as an instrumentation tool to harvest targeted playtest feedback for camera behavior and movement tuning.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining multiple playable levels in a demo becomes too costly while the engine, camera, and physics are still evolving.
key_stories.process: He identifies Course 1 as ideal for testing many camera edge cases (walls, poles, slides, open areas) and commits to releasing it with an organized feedback document.
key_stories.outcome: A workflow emerges: iterate Course 1 repeatedly, gather data, tune variables, then expand later once the core feel is locked in.
key_stories.key_quote: Course 1 has a lot of stuff that I need to test with the camera... so it makes for a very good test area.

key_stories.title: Building ‘flow’ into movement: the Goomba-bounce hold-jump
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates a new mechanic where holding A after a Goomba bounce produces a higher jump and restores control, inspired by classic 2D Mario. He connects it to a broader philosophy of removing ‘dead’ frames and making actions chain smoothly.
key_stories.challenge: Make movement feel modern and fluid while still ‘Mario-like,’ avoiding the stiffness of vanilla SM64’s input lockouts.
key_stories.process: He implements and tests the hold-A bounce behavior and emphasizes the overall removal of frames where the player can’t input during transitions.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze reports the game now feels so good that vanilla SM64 movement is hard to return to, reinforcing the hack’s identity around enhanced mobility.
key_stories.key_quote: Everything just flows into each other so much better.

key_stories.title: Blender 4.x migration pain: missing presets slow down N64 material work
key_stories.summary: While trying to quickly apply his standard material setups, Kaze discovers his user presets aren’t accessible in the new Blender environment. The moment turns into an on-stream derail, revealing how much his N64 workflow relies on reusable presets and stable tooling.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze can’t find or load his user presets/material presets after switching Blender versions, making repetitive tasks slower and more error-prone.
key_stories.process: He searches directories/UI, asks chat for the preset folder location, tests enabling/disabling Fast64, and considers copying from older installs but can’t locate the files reliably.
key_stories.outcome: He gives up mid-stream and proceeds manually, planning to work around it; the issue remains a potential time sink for future production.
key_stories.key_quote: I am so upset... I'm just gonna make no presets. I give up.

open_questions.topic: Course 1 demo feedback pipeline (what data, how to act on it)
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to re-release a Course 1-only demo with a Google Doc for camera/physics feedback, aiming to tune ‘little variables’ to perfection.
questions: What exact questions/metrics will you ask players to report (camera snag points, jump consistency, input feel), and how will you filter low-quality feedback?
How will you translate qualitative notes into concrete parameter changes—do you have a tuning checklist or rubric?
At what point will you consider the camera/physics ‘locked’ enough to stop using Course 1 as the main testbed?

open_questions.topic: Transparent render ordering and potential global layer swap
open_questions.context: Kaze suggests swapping how layer 5/6 are used because transparent decals rendering after transparent surfaces ‘makes no sense,’ implying a game-wide convention change.
questions: What specific visual bugs are caused by the current layer ordering, and where do they show up most clearly?
If you swap layer conventions across the entire game, what existing content breaks and how would you validate the change systematically?
Is there a long-term plan to standardize material/layer rules for contributors so these issues don’t reappear with future imports?

open_questions.topic: Course 11 crash and area streaming/visibility issues
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions an area that crashes on entry, and also notes cases where another area (e.g., underwater/blue area) appears visible/loaded from the main area, which could ‘mess with things.’
questions: What is the root cause of the crashing area—bad collision, a missing display list/material, object behavior, or area warp/streaming logic?
How do you decide what should be visible across areas, and what tooling do you use to detect overdraw/visibility leaks early?
Once fixed, will Course 11 become the new performance benchmark level for the project?

open_questions.topic: Easter egg room design: hamster-wheel Koopa and factory ‘state change’ illusion
open_questions.context: Biobak proposes an easter egg room where talking to a running Koopa triggers lights flicker and pipes shut down, making the room feel ‘part of the factory.’ Kaze discusses practical issues (player getting stuck, needing a closed door/bars, adding coins as purpose).
questions: Do you want these easter eggs to be purely comedic flavor, or to reward exploration with something tangible (coins, 1-ups, hints, etc.)?
How will you prevent softlocks and communicate to players that an easter egg area is non-critical?
What implementation approach will you use for the factory ‘power off’ illusion—screen overlay, per-room light toggles, texture swaps, scripted sequences?

open_questions.topic: Art consistency standards (billboards vs in-world style)
open_questions.context: A viewer critique makes Kaze question whether certain billboard Koopa faces clash with the rest of the game’s art style; he considers changing them despite being ‘in-world art.’
questions: Do you have (or want) a documented style guide for character faces/linework so background art matches foreground assets?
How do you decide when a ‘style mismatch’ is charming variety versus immersion-breaking inconsistency?
Would you rather re-draw the billboards, re-texture them, or justify them diegetically (e.g., different ‘brand’ art inside the world)?
